# Unit 13: Jacobians and Inverse Mappings

There are mappings, and there are inverse mappings. Of course.

![c6104a64.png](c6104a64-kl2ssw8c.png)

A mapping is said to be **one-to-one** (injective) iff $F(a,b) = F(c,d) \implies (a,b) = (c,d)$ for all points.

One-to-one implies Invertible.

![5553f451.png](5553f451-kl2ssw8b.png)

![c8ffaae6.png](c8ffaae6-kl2ssw8c.png)

Remember that a square matrix has an inverse iff its determinant is non-zero.

![919543c4.png](919543c4-kl2ssw8b.png)

![a385a241.png](a385a241-kl2ssw8b.png)

![dfa2cb80.png](dfa2cb80-kl2ssw8c.png)

---

Remember that the determinant of a matrix made up of 2d vectors is the area o the parallelagram described by them. The Jacobian of the mapping F describes the extent F increases or decreases areas. For small areas, multiplying the area in $xy$ with the Jacobian gives a good approximation of the area in $uv$.

This idea also extends to 3D: the jacobian is like the approximate volume magnification factor.

![1c2e3b70.png](1c2e3b70-kl2ssw8b.png)

---

## Constructing Mappings

When working with multi-integrals, it's important to construct mappings that are invertable that transforms one region into a simpler region.

Basically, look at the shape, then try to find **linear** equations $u=f(x,y)$ and $v=g(x,y)$ such that the boundaries of the parallelogram line up to a square. If the mapping is linear, that means that the linear approximation is  a perfect approximation. This means that multiplying the area by the jacobian will actually yeild the correct area in the mapped domain. or you could divide to go the other way.
